unnormalised: ## Return to Sender? Navigating the Labyrinthine World of Return Policies
normalised: ## Return to Sender? Navigating the Labyrinthine World of Return Policies

unnormalised: Let's be honest, folks. We've all been there. You order that snazzy kurta online from Myntra, picturing yourself looking like a million rupees at your cousin Priya's wedding in Delhi. But what arrives? Something resembling a dishrag, and suddenly you're singing the blues, not the latest Bollywood hit. That's when the dreaded "Return Policy" looms large like a grumpy aunty guarding the gate to the promised land.
normalised: Let's be honest, folks. We've all been there. You order that snazzy kurta online from Myntra, picturing yourself looking like a million rupees at your cousin Priya's wedding in Delhi. But what arrives? Something resembling a dishrag, and suddenly you're singing the blues, not the latest Bollywood hit. That's when the dreaded "Return Policy" looms large like a grumpy aunty guarding the gate to the promised land.

unnormalised: Return policies, my friends, are the Bhagavad Gita of online shopping – complex, often contradictory, and seemingly designed to test your patience. You spend 45 minutes deciphering the fine print only to discover it applies to everything EXCEPT the specific shade of 'electric blue' you unfortunately chose. They demand the item be returned in "original packaging, unworn, with all tags attached." Seriously? Did they expect you to try on the kurta through the packaging like some kind of Swami with X-ray vision?

You spend forty five minutes deciphering the fine print only to discover it applies to everything EXCEPT the specific shade of 'electric blue' you unfortunately chose. They demand the item be returned in "original packaging, unworn, with all tags attached." Seriously? Did they expect you to try on the kurta through the packaging like some kind of Swami with X-ray vision?

unnormalised: And the timelines! You have precisely 7 days from 15/08/1947 (Independence Day joke, chill!) to initiate a return. Miss that deadline, and you're stuck with the dishrag, destined to become the world's most uncomfortable floor cleaner.
normalised: And the timelines! You have precisely seven days from fifteenth august nineteen forty seven (Independence Day joke, chill!) to initiate a return. Miss that deadline, and you're stuck with the dishrag, destined to become the world's most uncomfortable floor cleaner.

unnormalised: Then there's the return shipping. Some companies, bless their souls, offer free returns. Others? You're suddenly facing a courier charge equivalent to flying your item back to Flipkart headquarters in Bangalore yourself! Seriously, I could probably drive to Agra and back faster than some of these return processes.

unnormalised: I once spent a delightful afternoon arguing with customer service at 09:00 hrs because they claimed my return request was filed at "Invalid Date." Turns out, their system didn't like the MM/DD/YYYY format, even though it was specified. Jai Hind!

unnormalised: And don't even get me started on 'final sale' items. Those are the items that are so unpopular, they’ve been permanently banished from polite society.
normalised: And don't even get me started on 'final sale' items. Those are the items that are so unpopular, they’ve been permanently banished from polite society.

unnormalised: So, before you click "add to cart," remember to scrutinize that return policy like you're planning the perfect Diwali bonus negotiation on 31/10/2024. It might just save you from a world of heartache (and a very ugly kurta). Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a dishrag to return. Wish me luck.
